Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we highly encourage you download the web wallet in a trusted way, instead of relying on DNS, but we will be having a public web wallet, since people freak out if we don't have it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if you download the web wallet and go to it with file:/// in your browser, it's waaaay safer, but not as safe as a full node wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> also, just to remind people, our new chain will be TINY, so in the beginning, our full node wallets will only need to download a few megabytes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's a great time to start using a full node, because there is no long big initial sync!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we are essentially compressing the history of our chain with gzip, and the output is just a few megabytes, my guess is around 50MB for our new chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> for reference, current Hush blockchain is 3.4 GB

Author: Gateway#3763

Content: [dscrd-hush] <LocoMB> ok I am just trying the swing wallet from the website

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> @dukeleto

is there a way to cyclically repeat the chain compression/snapshot to keep it within a reasonable size?

idk if any coin does this

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Spartacus yes, you can basically do what we are doing once every X years, compress all of history down to just "who owns money right now?"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> one issue is that you will lose access to encrypted memo field data, that is not transported to the new chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's a lossy compression, what is preserved is "who owns what" but not every bit of metadata. This could be seen as a feature or bug.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Feature if you want to be forgotten, bug if you are a whistleblower trying to prove something

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> okay, but what about it being a feature vs manual intervention?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's a manual thing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the only reason we are doing any of this because of a mind-bending bug in Sprout zaddrs, that is so bad that anything we do to fix it is better than leaving it alone

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> e.g. every 500k-th block, a snapshot is triggered and transitioned into over the next N+5000 blocks
the new chain starts from 5001

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> normal BTC-ish chains could do this compression thing, with no loss of encrypted stuff, because they don't have that. But you lose your transaction history

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Spartacus it sounds cool but it's not going to happen, making a new genesis block is a manual thing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> but we could do it every X years to keep our chain size under Y GB

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> something like that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> yeah, i figure if btc people can live with 210gb of space for a full node, there are reasons to keep it as it is

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> immutability is a big thing, being able to go back and look at a btc transaction 5 years ago on an explorer, etc...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> or the fact that eth simply never syncs anymore for the end-user üòÑ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> quick sync gets interrupted - good luck

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Spartacus> i've had my machine on for weeks on high-speed internet and an SSD and it never caught up

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> it would be possible to create snapshots automatically and have archival storage of the historical transactions, but making this seamless and bugfree, it is a lot of work

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <TheTrunk> I cannot alter all decisions Zel is doing. Hush explorer will remain up for a few weeks after the fork but will be on an old chain.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> iguana had this type of architecture where the historical blocks ended up in read only storage

Author: Gateway#3763

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @TheTrunk we have various explorers planned for the new Hush chain, so having one to compare against the old chain is useful

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Captain yes, it is

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <gilardh> @dukeleto I am not sure I understood the question, but I will try to answer it anyway. It is possible to change the address of the API used by the web wallet. I wanted to test the setting up of a drop-down list allowing to choose / change the address of the API quickly by the user.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that sounds useful, to choose your API server

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @LocoMB if your funds are in 1 or a few addresses, having the private keys of those are very useful and will import into many tools. The web wallet seed phrase is specific to the web wallet, like an electrum seed phrase is specific to electrum
